plist.p: Good morning, everyone. I will do the introduction and highlights and then we'll hand over to Richard and Gary, and then I will summarize at the end.
I think you will see sales increase by 33% to €892 million, 24% constant exchange rates. Excluding the impact of NET-A-PORTER, sales increased by 19% at constant rates.

Operating profit increased by 63% to €1,355 billion. The operating margin increased by 370 basis points to 19.7% of sales, excluding the impact of NET-A-PORTER, which we'll discuss again later on in more detail. The operating margin would have been just under 21% of sales.

Net cash improved – sorry – maybe you have to do it. Net cash position improved by €707 million to €2,589 billion. The increase included a record level of cash flow from operations of €1.696 billion just under €1.7 billion.

All right, if we go to sales and profit by segment, you will see that trading conditions were more favorable than the comparative period, which also included the destocking impact on wholesale sales, together positive exchange rates contributed and acquisitions contributed to 14 percentage points on the sales growth.
The operating margins of the jewelry and watchmaker segments were 31% and 21% respectively, at least three percentage points above last year.
Sales are broadly in line with forecast and additional profit stemmed from the higher reported sales improvements in the gross margin percentage and continued cost control.

Want to go to the sales analysis. At constant exchange rates and excluding acquisitions, group sales was 19%. Where are we now? I thought so – sorry, in my section I changed some things last night in my section they forgot to put the tabs in. I am back three pages, which you will see at the end. The rest they write for me.

So now, let's come to the analysis of sales for this fiscal year, first Europe that contributes to 38% of sales. Sales in Western Europe, plus 21% at constant rates, sales to local clientele progressing in France, Germany and Switzerland, thanks to timely imitative such as the relaunch of the Trinity and Love collections at Cartier.

Non-locals to continue to account for more than 50% of sales in Europe. Middle-East and Russia are back to growth, albeit at a slower rate, respectively plus 10% and plus 5%. Excluding high jewelery sales, the underlying trend in both markets is stronger. The inflation in commodity prices bode well for the future for these two markets.

Now Asia-Pacific, with 30% of Group sales, it's close to being our largest region. In terms of retail sales Hong Kong – the City of Hong Kong has become number one rate of Paris (0:05:09). Growth tracked that of other region when discounting the positive impact of NET-A-PORTER acquisition, year-on-year up 36% reflecting, an excellent performance across the region and successful opening of 55 stores, including internalization of franchise stores in Mainland China. Given the economic momentum and demographic base of the region, we expect an increase from Asia-Pacific to Group sales and to profit in the coming years.

Let's turn to the Americas region, 4% of Group sales, in excess of America 11%. Plus 30% to be compared to minus 20% last year, so comparatives are flattering. Strong retail up 25% excluding NET-A-PORTER plus 51% including NET-A-PORTER.
Wholesale did very well, up 15% given the substantial reduction of the network. As a result, division's distribution strategy will be pursued.

The very high end sales are particularly well reflecting a positive feel-good factor among our clients. We are confident that we have the ability to generate new wealth longer term increase purchases from South American, visitor should be a further contributor to the growth for that region.

Now Japan, our third largest single market after Hong Kong and the USA, contributing 11% of sales, more when accounting for Japanese tourists who are traveling against with the strong yen. Sales up by 1% in yen plus 18% in euro, benefiting from the strong yen.

Again, market share in shrinking pie by launching assorted products such as the Cartier rejuvenated Trinity Bijoux or the Charms Mini watches. Recent dramatic events are making it too difficult to access, but prospects likely to be brighter than most anticipated. March sales which are included in our results dropped by 21% in yen. In April, sales rose by 3% in yen.

I would like to add that, Richemont management and staff are very supportive and full of admiration for our Japanese colleagues and the Japanese people and the way they are coping with this dramatic events.

Finally, sales to our directly operated stores, operated stores and NET-A-PORTER i.e. retail sales, which represents 50% of Group sales. They grew by 35% or 24% without NET-A-PORTER, showing excellent momentum, benefiting from impactful store openings and from superior growth in Asia Pacific and with watches.

The wholesale performance at plus 15%, reflects a continuously strong replenishment from watch retailers, however limited by shortages, despite smaller distribution network, underlining an improvement in productivity for this network.

Let's look at the performance per segment now, and let's start with the jewelery maisons, record sales and profits for both Cartier and Van Cleef & Arpels, leading to a record profitability for the segment.

Cartier growth was again broad based in terms of geography and product line. The performance was particularly remarkable in retail. Beyond this is excellent performance Cartier has proven its ability to increase its leadership and amid extreme volatility thanks to a very reactive organization.

Likewise, Van Cleef & Arpels recorded a double-digit growth in France in all product lines and regions. Operating contribution for the jewelery segment increased by 43% to €1.62 billion giving a record contribution margin of 31%.

Now our specialist watchmakers, they all enjoyed very strong growth rates in sales except from – for Baume & Mercier due to the announced ongoing restructuring. The negative impact of the stronger Swiss francs, higher precious materials prices and product returns, and the cost – returns on the cost of sales were partially absorbed by price increases and higher production levels. As a result, operating contribution arose to €379 million and the contribution margin to 21%.

All specialist watchmakers saw an improvement in the results to reach an all-time high, with a special mention for the exceptional performance of Piaget and excellent management of transition year at Baume & Mercier, where relaunch sounds promising.
We are benefiting from a Korean portfolio focused on the premium segments and the watch industry which has been growing the fastest and with little cannibalization among Masons

Montblanc maison, all regions and channel enjoyed a double-digit growth rate in sales. Watches, leather goods and writing instruments showed very good growth in sales. As a consequence and thanks to a better utilization of manufacturing capacity and a more efficient retail network, the operating contribution rose by 38%. The contribution margin further progressed to reach 16% of sales.

Other – finally the other business area, this segment comprises the fashion and accessories, maison, NET-A-PORTER, and the facilities involved in the manufacturing of watch components to third-party and to our maisons.
The fashion and accessories business generated €29 million profit against a €8 million profit last year. Alfred Dunhill, Lancel, Chloé, Azzédine Alaïa and Shanghai Tang were all profitable.
In manufacturing, losses were reduced from €44 million to €35 million, thanks to improving order flows albeit still down, and improved productivity gains.
As a reminder, this segment also includes inter group subsidiaries which compensate for the incremental cost of components linked to integration. I'll deal with NET-A-PORTER in the next slide.

NET-A-PORTER enjoyed a superior growth in sales of 108% of €281 million in March 2011. I remember that NET-A-PORTER compared to other businesses has a specific business model, is distributing third-parties' products over Internet. It enjoys retailer gross margin maximum 50%.

On the other hand, it had lower AP ratio, mid to high-single digits. The business is running ahead of plan with a positive EBITDA generation and already significantly cash positive. We believe there is a significant potential ahead with further geographic expansion at NET-A-PORTER and OUTNET.COM and the launch of MR PORTER.

Organizational highlights. We are constantly working on improving the efficiency of our business mode. First, we are upgrading our backbone system and processes to adapt to a bigger and more volatile world. Optimization of supply chain will increase our competitive advantage.

In Asia-Pacific, in particular, in China, we're really investing in people, infrastructure to meet the challenges ahead of us. We'll have close to 2500 employees by the end of March 2012 against 1700 now in China.

Ongoing development of SAP, which is a distribution platform for the jewelery maisons and Specialist Watchmakers, to be completed in Europe, end of 2013. In production, Cartier is fully integrated and we are continuing the rollout with the Specialist Watchmakers starting with IWC this year.
New retail system at fashion and accessories maisons headquarters is now operational and regional rollout is underway.

Second, we maintain regional focus on growth markets where we see supplier growth, in Asia Pacific, where we open 55 internal stores. In the Middle-East, we also opened stores notably in Abu Dhabi, Dubai and Qatar. Finally, we opened few flagship stores discriminately in main location of established markets for specialist watchmakers like for example, Piaget in London and IWC in Paris.

Third, we exercised retail control of the distribution to enhance the shopping experience and grow productivity. Opening more mono-brand stores either fully owned franchise in new markets where there is no historical watch wholesale network and where cost of stores are lower. It makes sense to favor the opening of internal stores. These stores also act as an effective communication tool.

However, we shall continue to work with franchise partners and multi-brand retailers even in new markets. We will nevertheless continue with our strategy of having fewer partners and more partnership. For instance, Baume & Mercier has half the number of doors in services. It plans to maintain this number constant while opening new relationships in growth markets.

Fourth, support such growth with further investments in production, in terms of increased integration levels, increased efficiency and increased capacity. For the next three years we are continuing our integration plan and still subsidizing the incremental cost of integration linked to volume. By so doing, we are enabling our maison to adapt to improve our productivity and develop more upscale in-house movements
And over to you, Gary for the figures.

Thank you, Richard. Good morning to everyone in the hall and also watching on the web. First, we'll start with gross profit. Gross profit rose by 38% to €4.4 billion. This represents 63.7% of sales, a 210 basis point improvement on the previous year. Excluding NET-A-PORTER, which as Richard said enjoys only a retail margin. Overall, margins increased to 64.3% of sales.

This improvement reflects pricing power of our maisons, higher production levels and capacity utilization, the outperformance of retail versus wholesale channel. And this performance is in spite of a strengthening Swiss franc, particularly in the second half of the year.

And let's not forget as well, we did restructure Baume & Mercier in the second half and this had impacts both on the sales and margin line and provisioning of inventories. Nearly all of the maisons, increased their gross margins, particular increases were noted in Jaeger-LeCoultre, Alfred Dunhill and Lange & Söhne.

Let's turn to the operating expenses. Operating expenses grew by 29% or 13% at constant currency, excluding NET-A-PORTER which was well below the sales growth. Our overall ratio has been reduced to 44% of sales from 46%.

If I can draw your attention to the bridge in the upper right-hand corner of the slide, what's the bridge from year-on-year? We had a weaker euro that impacted 9% on the expenses. At the half year it was 8%.

The integration of NET-A-PORTER added 7% to the expense base. It was 7% in the first half. We increased our communication spend that added 6% on the total expense base. I will remind you at the half year it was 3% and we communicated a significant increase in the second half which came true.

All other costs are the S&D and admin, which rose by 7%. In the first half of the year those costs rose by 8% on the expense base. S&D costs 54% of the total OpEx rose by 30%. These increases obviously relate to new stores. We opened up 59 new stores for the year, mostly in the Asia-Pacific region. Our underlying growth of selling and distribution cost was 14% for the year.

Communication costs, as I mentioned were up 38%. We're back to a more normalized level of 10% of sales versus 8% in the previous year. Administration costs were up 20%, but on an underlying basis, excluding NET-A-PORTER and excluding constant currencies they rose by 3%.

Let's move now to the operating profit overview snapshot of the P&L. As Richard and Johann said, sales rose by 33% or 19% at constant currencies and excluding NET-A-PORTER. We had much improved gross margin, 63.7% or 64.3% without NET-A-PORTER. We have contained underling growth in expenses and this will lead to an operating profit rising by 63% to €1.355 billion and the leverage there is almost two to one.
Our overall operating margin was 19.7%, however if we exclude the impact of NET-A-PORTER, our operating margin arrived at 20.9%, which equaled our record margins that we achieved in 2008.

Let's look at the items below the operating line. Net finance costs amounted to €181 million. €150 million of this relates to the mark-to-market losses on our cash balances which we discussed at the half year. As a reminder, this has no effect on the equity position of the Group after consolidation. We recorded a one-time accounting gain of €101 million after our acquisition of NET-A-PORTER, because we had to revalue our initial 33% stake that happened in the first half.

Our tax rate came in at 16.7%. If you remember, last year, we did enjoy significant benefits on deferred tax assets that we had to record related to our stock option plan. That was about 220 basis points, if you exclude that, the normalized rate is about the same. We do continue to expect the tax rate to be around 18% in the medium-term. As a result, net profit for the year rose 80% to €1.079, passing the €1 billion mark for the first time. This represented 15.7% of sales.

Let's now focus on the cash flow. We enjoyed €232 million improvements for the year. Obviously a result of the higher operating profits and a quite limited swing in the working capital usage, despite the rebound in sales. The main elements of the working capital movements were increases in inventory. Our raw materials and work-in-process year-on-year rose by 44% and our finished goods rose by 13%.

We have enjoyed a faster inventory rotation this year, 16.5 months versus 18.7 a year ago. Accounts receivables continue to be managed well and collected timely and this I think is more a function of the desirability of our products in the wholesale channel and the turn that they enjoy. And we had some timing issues of the year-end in terms of trade payments and accruals as well and that had a positive impact.

We did manage to grow and we did manage to manage our inventories around the constrains that we had. We do expect an increase in the coming year in terms of finished goods inventories, because the current levels we believe are lower than we would like.

Let's now take a look at our fixed asset investments. Gross fixed assets were up 89% to 4.1% of sales. We increased investments in our retail network, our manufacturing facilities. And we expanded our distribution platforms for NET-A-PORTER.

At €285 million gross spend this is still above our depreciation level of €213 million for the year. For the next year, we anticipate fixed asset investments to approximate 6% to 7% of sales and we expect 7% to 8% of sales in fiscal '13.

Let's go through some details of the fixed asset spend. By category, nearly half of our investments relate to our retail and point of sale networks. The most notable projects for the year, the Singapore Marina Bay Sands project, where we have eight boutiques, eight brands; Piaget Bond Street in London and Panerai in Paris on Rue de la Paix.

Cartier renovated its flagship in Hong Kong, the Prince's building and also opened up locations in Shanghai, Hong Kong Plaza and Macau the Wynn project. Close to 30% of our spend were in our manufacturing capabilities. Most of this spend relates to tools. We didn't really have any spend on space this year. And the remaining 23% includes the new distribution platforms as we suggested associated with NET-A-PORTER and ERP systems.

Let's go to the final operational element, free cash flow. Free cash flow for the year amounted to €915 million approximately €1.1 billion if you exclude the acquisition of NET-A-PORTER. This obviously reflects the higher operating results, reasonable retention of working capital and higher tax payments.

Let's take a quick look at the balance sheet. We continue to enjoy a solid balance sheet. Equity rose to 72% of the total from 70 last year. After a dividend payment this year of a €141 million and our investment in NET-A-PORTER, our net cash and investments position rose from €1.9 billion to €2.6 billion at the end of the year.
I would like to now turn it over to Mr. Johann Rupert for our summary. Thank you.

Okay. Let's see now that I have the right document. Right. I actually wanted just to slide up, but I redid it and I sent them the slides, so they must have been reformatted. Now what you've seen up till now is really the last year, but I like to just step back to what the underlying goals and strategy will entail for the future. And the results that we've seen up till now has been as a result of us concentrating on a few basic principles.

Obviously, we'd like to grow the value of our company, your – our – the shareholder in a sustainable way. Now that will be valued by the markets, because of the sustainable flow of dividends. We've said in the past that we like to keep it growing at about 15% over a medium to long-term. Don't hold me to that, we'll probably, as in the past have a higher payout ratio in bad times and a lower payout ratio in good times. Obviously, this depends upon the growth in free cash flow. We do not tie ourselves to payout ratios.

Next please. Now obviously, we're not going to have any sales of our products that don't appeal to clients on a worldwide basis. We've been fortunate in going to what we call growth markets today at an early stage. The key to desirability is – really lies in integrity of the brand of the maison and the esteem.

Therefore, we started verticalizing our watch production. I'd say in the late 90s and it accelerated with the acquisition of LMH. So today, we have some 21 factories, employing nearly 7,000 people in Switzerland.

Clients are too intelligent. They don't want to buy a Ferrari made in a Fiat factory. That was our like motive, and why we accentuated verticalization, and I would say before the great number of our competitors. And obviously, you need awareness as well. It's no good if you have a hidden gem and nobody knows about it. So, we have to spend on communication. And you'll see that in bad times we'll tend to spend more as a percentage of sales because we intend to keep our share of voice.

Then our products must also be relevant. You can have the best probable in the world, if it's not relevant to the consumer, they won't buy it. And the brand needs vitality. So we need creativity. We need younger people and this goes right through to the HR policies throughout the different maisons.

So we try to bode brand equity, desirability, which leads to pricing power, because you know what's happened to the Swiss franc and to the euro versus the dollar for instance where a great number of our clients love in dollar related currencies. And unless you've got pricing power, you're also not going to be able to sell. So it's a matrix. We think we understand the matrix, then that's the Holy Grail. Next please.

Why did I tell you all of that because Gary has already referred to CapEx, obviously expenditure on boutiques. We intend to further expand networks in growth areas and to consistently and continuously keep the quality of our boutiques at the premium – super premium level.

We will further spend on our industrial capacity and on our research and development. We are again in a fortunate position that we cannot supply the demand and that's across-the-board and we will not be tempted to pick low hanging fruit. We will make sure that we will have the necessary people with the necessary skills in the necessary manufacturing sites, in order not to produce products that we're not proud off. I've already discussed the boutiques, Gary has referred to it.

And our overall preference folks, is to build goodwill rather than brand equity rather than to buy it. We've also been offered a lot of the companies that have been sold, in fact, prior to other people having bought it or bought them. But the call that we've got to make is do we pay somebody else billions of euro of which billions of euro is represented in goodwill or we take – do we take a €1 billion for instance and expand the boutiques of Cartier, Van Cleef and Piaget. And we made the call that we will serve our shareholders better by doing the latter. Next one please.

Now you've seen that by network this is April, we've done well, at constant currencies it's 35% up. Retail was up 45%, wholesale 27%. Japan was single-digit and Asia Pacific and Europe up double-digit. Thank you.

Now the conclusion. We've got a unique portfolio of high quality maisons. We've got leadership in prestige jewelery and watches. I never thought when we started here in 1988 that we would be called an emerging market play. I mean not in my wildest dreams did I ever think that we'd making watches. I don't think we'll say making jewelry, I would say creating jewelry. And that an American fund manager would tell me you are a key emerging market player. And what are you talking about the emerging market play. So don't you actually understand what I mean. But we are in effect, as I think it was Coco Chanel that said money is money is money, it's only the pockets that change. So we are very fortunate that the work that's been done by our predecessors, by our current colleagues, I would say by the people in the room, they enter the maisons.

It's led to a banner for mass sales, plane with five engines. So if the one engine starts stuttering because of economic problems, let's say the United States, Europe – parts of Europe. Then luckily we have Asian engines and they came to balance themselves because the most of our maisons have universal appeal, which is this broad exposure to local clientele from traditional established markets and the clientele from the growth markets.

We have a strong balance sheet as said, firstly you can discount us ever using equity for acquisition. Equity is always the most expensive way to pay. And our cash, we feel is better deployed in supporting maisons that we know and that we see growing faster in target areas than the companies that's available for sale.
Thank you very much. We are ready to take some questions now.
The hands are up already.

Yes. Good morning. Jon Cox, with Kepler Capital Markets. A couple of questions for you. The first question, just on the profitability of the watch division in the second half of the year appeared to halve. I wonder if you could just give us some more detail on that. Even adding back your one-off restructuring your one-off restructuring still looks pretty disappointing compared to what you have in the first half of the year?

Second question for you, just on the net cash power you have the dividend seemed to relatively light given the big net cash power you had, just wondering, obviously you've talked about an expansion of CapEx, but even that won't get rid of that huge cash power you have. But you are clearly ruling out any big M&A. I'm just wondering, if you thought about maybe a buyback to return cash to shareholders or a special dividend? Thank you.

I lost a second, but Jon, you're English speaking. I thought I had explained and I've known you for so many years. I've thought I've explained it again and again and again and again that a payout ratio is different in good years to bad years. And I'm not sure we are out of the woods yet. In fact, I'm not talking about threshold, I'm talking about the world economy.

If you look at the debt restructuring in Europe and you look at the debt ceilings in the United States, it's as if we are dancing on clouds. You see the VIX is universal optimism. And I have said that to the shareholders years ago we will try to grow by 15% per year and we will carry on to doing that. And in fact it's really because of the lack of regulatory supervision and because of active shareholders prodded on like market commentators.

That part of the problem that we're in, exists today. When I started banks and automobile companies were allowed to have hidden reserves. So in fact here guess what's happened, the banks created hidden reserves and so did the automobile companies been involved I was in the Board, in the Advisory Board of automobile companies that puts away billions of, let's say that used to be Deutsche Marks in the lean year. Guess what happened, various accounting standards changed there to bring it on to the balance sheet. Active shareholders said, you got lazy balance sheet, give us the cash. The management found it, they gave the cash, the famous line, give it back to you when you need it, and of course we all know that's a total fallacy.

So the companies gave back ridiculously low interest rates prevailed and there were opiate in the air about leverage and everybody assumed leverage, the banks, the shadow banks. Guess what happened, the taxpayers we bailed them out and that payback has to come sometime. So the debt is not disappeared. It's just morphed into a social obligation.

So, I'm afraid, to some extent profits got privatized and losses got socialized. That bill will have to be paid some time, either – and in the end, I'm afraid, the saver will suffer, whether it be through inflation or default.

And if you look at share buybacks, and at the prices where the companies bought their shares back, they inevitably bought the shares back very close to the top of the market because that's when they had a lot of cash and, boy do they regretted when two years later all hell breaks loose. We've had this policy since we went public and I think it stood our shareholders in good state. And to describe that it – to describe the 29%, nearly 30% increase in dividends as how will you put it poor or – sorry I missed your word – slight.
Light.

Light. You're clearly not as bigger shareholder as I am because I was very, very glad when the Board voted to increase it by 30%. As for the first one, they can explain it to you, please just explain to them the watch division.

Hi, Jon. How you are doing? The factors that we try to highlight in the first half, basically I think came true. We had a slight reduction relating to foreign exchange on the Group. We were positive in the first half and we were negative in the second half. That's one factor.

I would say in the watch division, generally the margin usually in the best of days is lower in the second half normally. We said we were going to spend more in communication. We spent about 8% group-wide in the first half and we spent 12 in the second half. And we tried to communicate the Baume & Mercier situation. What did I say at the half year? B&M was profitable in the first half, and we said we were going to invest. So, that the losses for Roger Dubuis and B&M together would be equal last year that implies a significant profit reduction in the second half and that's...
We – not a reposition – it was a conscious decision to reposition Baume and Mercier and unfortunately Gary then had to record the effects, Jon. But it wasn't – this was by design, not by accident.

I mean, if I would say, Jon the – I think the Baume & Mercier management team led by Alain Zimmermann they did a great job of this. They got the products ready. We reduced the doors by over 50%. We took back all the products from the doors that we were going forward with and we destroyed it. So starting April 1st, it's an extremely clean situation and we are pretty positive about it. I think it's – that one is going to be a quick turnaround.

But I think it's a good question, Jon because unless you understand that we deliberately decided to clean that we took the stock back. It was really a turnaround situation. I'm personally very excited, but what I see and especially by the response of the dealers and the people who came to the SIHH. But it would look funny if you didn't understand.

Rey Wium, Renaissance Capital. Just two questions. The first one, first just revolves around the Americas, obviously you've seen some quite strong growth out of that market of 30%. I am just curious to your views about the sustainability of that given that the American economy is not out of the woods, yet?

And the second question just regarding Montblanc, your margins were about 16% now and if I look at the product profile, you have leather in there, watches. My gut feel is that – I just want to know, is it possible for the margins to get closer to the likes of your jewelery maisons over the longer term?
America?
Yes.

First, remember that operating basis is flattering, we had a bigger drop last year in America, but that's very true that especially for the higher-end brand the recovery has been quite strong, the feel-good factor is there completely and is back and we are experiencing very good sales. I am not an expert in predicting how the economy is going and what we are seeing, but I may confirm in April time confirmed in April that business is back and the clients are already buying. Remember that during the crisis, we didn't try to push to sell in. We cleaned our distribution, so we have a very clean situation, of course, probably in Baume & Mercier, but for the other brand as well. We continue to reduce the network to have really first seeking to the shopping experience for the client to really be well treated. I guess you saw the interview on (50:28) regarding the American distribution. That's very clear that we tried to do our best to sell our products in the good condition. And that leads to another side benefit which is increase of productivity of the network, less loss, less cost and much, much nicer distribution.

And also, Richard, I might add, the dealers that – the doors that remain open, obviously do better, which leads to cleaner inventory in their positions. So it's all-in-all a same thing to do. As for America or Europe, I have absolutely no idea. But there is a remarkable correlation between some of our maisons and various stock exchanges and a negative correlation to the VIX.

People feel good. The fear factor is down and there are nice spend, it's been the case since time immemorial. And I guess my big fear is stagflation. You guys are too young to remember the 70s, but stagflation is a horrible thing. And so all-in-all I'm more pessimistic than I should be, considering the results. But that's for Europe and for United States, particularly, mainly Anglo-Saxon exuberance. And then of course, the sailors in Northern Europe having to pay for the people with a higher quality of life in Southern Europe. How long that is containable, I'm not sure. It's – you live in Hamburg, you pay high taxes and you work your backside off and you look on television you see this wonderful lifestyles next to the Mediterranean, I'm not sure. So I couldn't give you a view on the states I wouldn't' short the United States and I would certainly not short their ingenuity and capacity to work themselves out of situations. But as we've seen, we're very fortunate in that the sales are now more balanced. As for Montblanc, it currently stands at – sales mix is totally different and I think Gary and Richard can expand on that.

You know that Montblanc, for the first time we no longer call it the segment in writing instrument – it's Montblanc Mason, it's a transformation process. It has really become a luxury maison not only selling brands but watches, leather goods and jewelery. So in the process of building brand equity exactly was expressed by...

The other thing is – obviously if you more wholesale than retail it affects your business and they've invested heavily into watches and they're doing very well. They're both a very good watch business. In the year 2000-2001 I nearly had a heart attack when Jan du Plessis, we had a perfect strong – strong yen, weak euro, the millennium fervor and he made a statement, and he thinks we can maintain 20%, I said, we won't here, but I said

Jan, please if you guys ought to – as he sat down, I said are you out of your mind, Are we going to keep on having operate – you remember the conversation. So I don't know, we will try and help them with from the head office, but you've got to remember that in Hamburg they run autonomously. It will depend upon their product mix and it will depend upon the geographic footprint to a very large extent. Have you got, Gary anything?
The bean counter from this end of the table, we'll always say, we want to increase our margins right. We – that's a stated goal that we have.
They also want to increase their margins, but you can't go, I want to increase – it takes a while.
Sure. But can we give you a target? Not really, because of the factors that the Chairman discussed. But...

Look at the footprint, America – Piaget one boutique in the one casino in Macau. Guys make money, they walk out, they are happy. Where do you think you get margins, but they've done a very good job, I mean their watches today are superb and they're beginning to do well. Well, they are doing well.

Good morning. Thomas Chauvet, Citigroup. I have three questions. The first one on your April current trading you've had a strong sales acceleration especially against the high comparative. I was wondering the reason behind it, if there was any one-off effects high jewels sales for instance. And in the release you seem to suggest that you expect these trends to continue in coming months. So I was wondering if you could talk a bit about the outlook in the coming months.

Secondly, on fashion and leather you've achieved a big turn around there a big swing in profits, I was wondering what's changed fundamentally at those businesses, and from a strategic point of view would you be tempted to use some of your high cash pile to maybe strengthen your presence in fashion and leather or you're pretty happy with the current brand portfolio.

Thirdly, on vertical integration, do you thing Swatch Group's intention to stop delivering movement to third parties are realistic threats. And if so, how quickly could you get more independent in terms of movement production. Thank you.
